metadata.title: Effects of chitosan/nano-silica on postharvest quality and antioxidant capacity of loquat fruit during cold storage

sections.text:
Effects of chitosan/nano-silica on postharvest quality and antioxidant capacity of loquat fruit during cold storage
Huwei Songa, Weiming Yuanb, Peng Jinc, Wei Wangd, Xinfeng Wanga, Liming Yanga,*, Yunfeng Zhanga
a Jiangsu Collaborative Innovation Center of Regional Modern Agriculture & Environmental Protection, College of Life Science, Huaiyin Normal University, No. 111 West Changjiang Road, Huaian 223300, Jiangsu, China bCollege of Horticulture Science and Technology, Suzhou Polytechnic Institute of Agriculture, NO. 279, Xiyuan Road, Suzhou 215008, Jiangsu, China cCollege of Food Science and Technology, Nanjing Agricultural University, Nanjing 210095, Jiangsu, China d School of Life Science, Anhui Agricultural University, 130 West Changjiang Road, Hefei 230036, Anhui, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 28 January 2016 Received in revised form 20 April 2016 Accepted 21 April 2016 Available online 3 May 2016
Keywords: Chilling injury Loquat Chitosan Nano-silica Physiological properties Oxidative damage
A B S T R A C T
Loquat (Eriobotrya japonica Lindl.) fruit has a very short shelf-life during ambient temperature storage, and is susceptible to cold storage appearing chilling injury symptoms. The effect of chitosan/nano-silica coating on chilling tolerance in white-flesh loquat fruit (cv Baiyu) stored at 5 C for 40 d was investigated. In comparison with control fruit, internal browning and weight loss in chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit were significantly delayed. Likewise, the decrease of total soluble solids (TSS) and titratable acidity (TA) was also inhibited. Glucose and fructose contents increased from 11.31 to 12.76 g kg 1 and from 33.20 to 44.37 g kg 1, respectively. The increase of reducing sugars contributed to the improvement of superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT) and ascorbate peroxidase (APX) activities, reaching the peaks of 623510.12, 462371.21 and 41114.35 U kg 1, respectively. Enhanced activities of antioxidant enzymes markedly alleviated the generation of superoxide anion (O2 ) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). Low levels of malondialdehyde (MDA) and membrane permeability in chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit were also detected, ranged from 4.35 to 8.31 mmol kg 1 and from 24.32 to 43.45%, respectively. Moreover, activities of phenylalanine ammonia-lyase (PAL), polyphenoloxidase (PPO) and lipoxidase (LOX) were also much lower than those in treatment alone and control fruit. Our results indicated that the use of chitosan/nanosilica coating was effective in enhancing chilling tolerance and providing a longer storage life with acceptable external and internal quality in loquat fruit.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Loquat (Eriobotrya japonica Lindl.) is a subtropical fruit popular for its flavor and nutritive value (Pareek et al., 2014). However, loquat fruit has very short shelf-life at ambient temperature due to

http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.postharvbio.2016.04.015 0925-5214/ã 2016 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
flesh browning and fungi decay (Cao et al., 2008). Low-temperature storage (1–5 C for 2–3 weeks) causes chilling injury symptoms such as flesh shrivel and internal browning. Although various methods such as low-temperature conditioning, hot air treatment, and application of 1-methylcyclopropene or methyl jasmonate have been demonstrated to reduce chilling injury of loquat fruit (Cai et al., 2006; Jin et al., 2014; Cao et al., 2009, 2011), few are used extensively in commercial situations at present (Cao et al., 2009). With the extensive use of cold chain storage during the postharvest transport of loquat fruit, there is still a need for developing more effective techniques to alleviate chilling injury (Jin et al., 2014).
Currently, some bio- or nano-based materials with improved mechanical barriers and antimicrobial properties provide a novel packaging technology in postharvest industry (Silvestre et al., 2011). We previously found that an integration of chitosan and
nano-silica greatly improved the quality of longan fruit during ambient temperature storage (Shi et al., 2013). However, effect of chitosan/nano-silica coating on alleviating chilling injury of perishable fruits has not been reported until now. Chilling injury induces fruit membrane damage and reactive oxygen species (ROS) production (Aghdam and Bodbodak, 2014). The injury alleviation is related to the ability to reduce and scavenge ROS by the increase of antioxidant enzyme activities (Cao et al., 2009). Partial antioxidant metabolism had been evaluated in enhancing fruit chilling tolerance during cold storage. Sugar metabolism is regarded as one of essential factors for biosynthesis of antioxidant molecules against oxidative chilling stress (Couée et al., 2006).
In our present study, a chitosan/nano-silica hybrid was successfully synthesized through the sol-gel approach. And its effects on fruit quality and chilling tolerance were evaluated using physiological indexes and antioxidant properties in white-flesh loquat (cv Baiyu) prone to quality recession and flesh browning at 5 C. Sugar types and contents under chilling stress were also investigated. The objective is to understand that antioxidant system and sugar composition are associated with enhancing chilling tolerance in chitosan/nano-silica treated loquat fruit during cold storage.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Loquat fruit (Eriobotrya japonica Lindl. cv Baiyu) were harvested from 12-year-old trees grown in the Loquat Germplasm Preservation Orchard of Jiangsu Province, Suzhou, China. The uniform fruit were selected in size, weight and color without signs of disease and pest damage. Chitosan (with 75.6% of deacetylation degree, CAS Number 9012-76-4, Batch 10305DD, Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO, USA) and glacial acetic acid (98%, v/v) were used to prepare the film-forming dispersion. Tetraorthosilicate [(C2H5O)4Si, TEOS, 98% purity] was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA).

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation and detection of the chitosan/nano-silica coating
sections.text: The chitosan/nano-silica coating was prepared according to the description of Yeh et al. (2007) and Lai et al. (2006) with some modification. Chitosan (0.75%, w/v) was dissolved in glacial acetic acid (1.0%, v/v) to form a viscous and pale yellow solution. The solution was stirred at 300 rpm for 8 h at room temperature. Silica solution was prepared at a molarratio of TEOS: deionized water: ethanol (1:4:1). After stirred at 200 rpm for 2 h, the solution was kept for 30 min at room temperature prior to mixing with the chitosan solution. The pH was adjusted to 5.6 with NaOH (1 mol L 1). Afterwards, the silica solution was added into the chitosan solution followed by an ultrasonication (KQ-250E, Kunshan Ultrasonic Instrument Co., Ltd., Kunshan, China) for 30 min under 300 W at 60 C. Sucrose ester of fatty acid (0.5%, v/v) was finally added and repeatedly stirred with a magnetic stirrer until the mixture solution became clear. Morphology of chitosan or/and nano-silica coating was examined by a transmission electron microscope (TEM, Hitachi, Model H-800, Japan.).

sections.heading: 2.3. Treatment and storage of loquat fruit
sections.text:
The selected fruit samples were distributed randomly into four groups. Four different treatments were used as following: (1) control (deionized water); (2) chitosan (0.75%, w/v); (3) nano-silica (30%, w/v) and (4) chitosan/nano-silica. The fruit samples from the same group were dipped into chitosan or/and nano-silica solutions for 5 min, respectively. The deionized water was used as a control.
All fruit samples were placed in 0.02 millimeter polyethylene bags and were kept at 5 C.

sections.heading: 2.4. Measurement of fruit weight loss and browning index
sections.text: Fresh weight loss was monitored at the interval of 5 d during storage at 5 C. The internal browning (IB) index manifested as browning discoloration near the core was evaluated visually after cutting the fruit longitudinally in half (Cao et al., 2009). For each fruit, IB was scored according to a 5-grade scale, where 0 = none (excellent quality), 1 = browning area < 5% (slight), 2 = browning area 5%–25% (moderate), 3 = browning area 25%–50% (moderately severe) and 4 = browning area > 50% (severe). An IB index was expressed using the following formula: IB index (between 0 and 4) = P [(browning rating) (fruit number at the browning rating)]/total fruit number.

sections.heading: 2.5. Determination of sugar contents
sections.text: 5 g of flesh tissue were homogenized in 20 mL of re-cold ethanol (95%, v/v). The extract was evaporated under vacuum at 35 C for removing the ethanol. The final volume was dilute with distilled water to 25 mL. After filtering with a 0.2 mm filter, 6 mL of the extract was passed through a Sep-Pak C18 cartridge (Waters, Milford, MA, USA) activated with acetonitrile and water (Cao et al., 2013). A 20-mL aliquot was injected into a high-performance liquid chromatography system in a Waters chromatograph equipped with a refractive index detector (Waters, Mildford, MA) and a CarboSep CHO-682 carbohydrate analysis column (Transgenomic, San Jose, CA). The separation was operated at 80 C with ultrapure water as a mobile-phase (0.5 mL min 1). Individual sugar was identified and quantified by comparison with the retention times and peak areas of individual sugar standard. The results were expressed as g kg 1.

sections.heading: 2.6. Determination of total soluble solids (TSS) and titratable acidity (TA) contents
sections.text: 5 g of flesh tissue from each replicate were homogenized and then centrifuged at 13,000g for 20 min. The supernatant was used to analyze TSS and TA contents (Cao et al., 2008). TSS (%) was determined using a digital pocket refractometer (PAL-a, ATAGO, Tokyo, Japan). TA was determined by titration with NaOH (0.1 mol L 1) until pH 8.1 and expressed as% malic acid (mass/mass).

sections.text:
), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), membrane permeability and malondialdehyde (MDA)
The rate of O2 production was calculated against a standard curve with NaNO2 as previously described by Cao et al. (2009). 5 g of flesh tissue were homogenized with 5 mL of phosphate buffer (50 mmol L 1, pH 7.8) and then centrifuged at 12,000g for 20 min at 4 C. 1 mL of hydroxyammonium chloride (1 mol L 1) was added to 1 mL of the supernatant, and the mixture was incubated at 25 C for 1 h. 2 mL of ether was added to prevent interference from chlorophyll. After centrifugation at 12,000g for 10 min, 1 mL of the supernatant was mixed with 1 mL of 17 mmol L 1 p-aminophenylsulfonic acid and 1 mL of 7 mmol L 1 a-naphthylamine at 25 C for 20 min. This rate was measured using the absorbance at 530 nm, and expressed as mmol min 1 kg 1.
H2O2 content was measured according to the method of Cao et al. (2009). 5 g of flesh tissue were homogenized with 30 mL of recold acetone, and centrifuged at 12,000g for 20 min at 4 C. The supernatant was mixed with hydrochloric acid (containing 200 mL L 1 TiCl4) and ammonia solution (17 mol L 1). The
precipitate was washed with acetone and dissolved in 2 mol L 1 sulfuric acid. Based on a standard graph, H2O2 content was monitored at 410 nm, and expressed as mmol kg 1.
MDA content was determined by the method of Hodges et al. (1999). 5 g of flesh tissue were homogenized in 20 mL of trichloroacetic acid (50 g L 1). After being heated at 95 C for 15 min, the mixture was quickly cooled and centrifuged at 12,000g for 15 min. The absorbance was read at 532 nm and corrected the unspecific turbidity by subtracting the absorbance at 600 nm. The results were expressed as mmol kg 1.
Membrane permeability was assessed by measuring the initial conductivity (EC0) and total conductivity (ECT) (Shao et al., 2013). The flesh disc was placed in 30 mL of 0.8 mmol L 1mannitol for 2 h. The conductivity (EC0) was measured with a conductivity meter (DDS-11A, Shanghai Precision Scientific Instrument Co., Ltd, China). After being boiled for 5 min, the total conductivity (ECT) was determined. The relative electric conductivity was calculated as: Relative electric conductivity (%) = (EC0/ECT) 100%.

sections.heading: 2.8. Activity determination of enzymes
sections.text:
All procedures of enzyme extraction were performed at 4 C. For enzyme extraction, 5 g of flesh tissue were homogenized in 25 mL of ice-cold extraction buffer containing 2% (w/v) polyvinyl polypyrrolidone. For superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT) and lipoxygenase (LOX) assay, the extraction buffer was 50 mmol L 1 sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.8). Sodium phosphate buffer (50 mmol L 1, pH 7.0) was used for determining ascorbate peroxidase (APX) activity. For polyphenol oxidase (PPO) and phenylalanine ammonia lyase (PAL) assay, 0.1 mol L 1 of sodium phosphate buffer (pH 6.8) containing 0.2 mmol L 1 of EDTA was used. After centrifugation at 12,000g for 20 min at 4 C, the supernatant was used directly for activity assay.
Fig.1. Schematic diagram of the preparation of different coatings. The chitosan (a), nanoformula (d) of the chitosan/nano-silica was also shown.
For determination of SOD, the reaction mixture (3 mL) contained 50 mmol L 1 sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.8), 14 mmol L 1 methionine, 3 mmol L 1 EDTA, 1 mmol L 1 nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT), 60 mmol L 1 riboflavin and 0.1 mL of enzyme extract. The formation of blue formazan was monitored by recording the absorbance at 560 nm. One unit of SOD activity was defined as the amount of enzyme that would inhibit 50% photoreduction of NBT.
CAT activity was measured according to the method of Cao et al. (2009). The reaction mixture consisted of 12.5 mmol L 1H2O2, 50 mmol L 1 sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0) and 0.2 mL of enzyme extract. The decomposition of H2O2 was determined by recording the absorbance at 240 nm every 2 min. One unit of CAT activity was expressed as the amount of enzyme that decomposed 1 mmol L 1 of H2O2 per min at 25 C.
For LOX activity, the reaction mixture contained 0.1 mol L 1 sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0), 50 mmol L 1 sodium linoleic acid solution and 0.2 mL of enzyme extract. The increase was measured by recording the absorbance at 234 nm. One unit of LOX activity was defined as the amount of enzyme that caused a change of 0.01 in absorbance per min.
APX activity was measured by the method of Nakano and Asada (1989). The reaction mixture contained 50 mmol L 1 sodium phosphate buffer (pH 7.0), 9 mmol L 1 ascorbic acid, 12.5 mmol L 1 H2O2 and 0.1 mL of enzyme extract. The activity was calculated from a change in absorbance at 290 nm for per min when the extinction coefficient was 2.8 mmol L 1 cm 1.
PPO activity was determined according to the method of Chazarra et al. (2001). 50 mL of enzyme extract was added to 500 mmol L 1 catechol substrate in 100 mmol L 1 sodium phosphate buffer (pH 6.4). The increase in absorbance at 400 nm was measured after 1 mL H2O2was added. The activity was defined as a change of 0.001 in absorbance per min in OD400.

sections.heading: 2.9. Statistical analysis
sections.text: One hundred fruit samples were randomly separated into four lots for deferent treatments at each stage. The storage periods were sustained initially up to 40 d after harvest at 5 C. Each treatment of 25 fruit samples containing three replicates in each experiment was repeated at each time point. All data were expressed as means the standard error (SE) and subjected to statistical analysis with the SPSS Version 13.0 software (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA). One-way ANOVA was also performed for each level of each factor. Two-way ANOVA was performed to determine the effect of treatment, storage time and treatment * time on quality attributes and enzyme activates. Significant differences between means were determined by Tukey post hoc comparison tests at p < 0.05.

sections.heading: 3.1. Characteristics of the chitosan/nano-silica coating
sections.text:
Conventional polymer composites were formed through a simple blend, lacking of substantial interaction between the dispersed filler and the polymer matrix (Lai et al., 2006). Recently, the organic-inorganic hybrid with nanostructure was developed through the sol-gel method (Li et al., 2008). Chitosan was considered as an attractive biopolymer due to its advantageous properties in food industry. In our study, the chitosan/nano-silica coating was formed by the reaction of partially co-condensed silica from TEOS with chitosan solution (Fig. 1). A diffused network of nano-silica in chitosan matrix was generated by the formation of Si O C bonds and hydrogen (N:H) bonds (Lai et al., 2006; Yeh et al., 2007). In comparison with the tightly compacted chitosan or
Fig. 2. Effects of chitosan or/and nano-silica treatments on levels of glucose (a), fructose are the means of three replicates (25 fruit samples each) from three experiments. Value same sampling time. Vertical bars represent the standard errors of the means.
nano-silica gel, the chitosan/nano-silica coating exhibited a highly porous structure, characterized by TEM (Fig.1). In addition, the solgel coating can reduce the hydrophobicity of material, inhibit activities of immobilized enzymes, and increase the self-chemical stability in the aqueous solvent (Li et al., 2008; Shi et al., 2013). Therefore, the biodegradable coating will be of great commercial interest for ecological advantage and sustainable development.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of chitosan/nano-silica treatment on sugar accumulation
sections.text:
Sugar contents and types were closely related to storage periods. During the first 10 d of storage, contents of glucose and fructose initially declined, and then increased in control fruit (Fig. 2a and b). Chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit showed that glucose and fructose had a dramatic accumulation in comparison with each treatment alone or control group. This is supported with high F-value of 363.90 (glucose content) and 376.26 (fructose content) between different treatments (Supplementary Table 1). No obvious differences glucose (p = 0.06) and fructose (p = 0.83) were observed between chitosan and nano-silica treated fruit. Interestingly, sucrose contents declined sharply along with storage time in all treated fruit samples, which maintained profoundly lower sucrose contents than that in control fruit (Fig. 2c). An analogous result had been observed in the heat-induced chilling resistance of loquat fruit during cold storage (Shao et al., 2013). Ding et al. (1998) also showed that sucrose declined rapidly in the ‘Mogi’ loquat fruit and the rate of decline was greater with the increase of storage temperature.
The increase of chilling injury and storage temperature causes fruit softening and senescence, resulting in the rise of ROS levels. Reducing sugars, especially glucose and fructose, were recognized as crucial compounds in protecting plants from chilling injury and oxidative stress (Cao et al., 2013). The protective roles of soluble sugars against oxidative stress not only were attributed to the increment of antioxidant ability but also were due to their ROS scavenging activity (Van den Ende and Valluru 2009). Glucose was a powerful precursor for ascorbic acid (AA) biosynthesis and

carbon skeletons of amino acids such as glutamic acid, which was the backbone of glutathione-S-transferase (GSH) biosynthesis (Smirnoff et al., 2001). Enhanced glucose in loquat fruit treated with hot air could activate the oxidative pentose phosphate pathway and lead to higher NADPH, a major reducing molecule in the AA-GSH cycle (de Carvalho 2008). AA and GSH accumulation contributed to the maintenance of membrane integrity and protein function. Liu et al. (2013) also found that sugar metabolism was related to the alleviation of oxidative stress via facilitating hot shock proteins as well as antioxidant molecules such as AA and GSH accumulation. Therefore, higher glucose content in loquat fruit treated with chitosan/nano-silica may contribute to the mitigation of oxidative stress by the improvement of AA and GSH contents and the enhancement of APX and glutathione reductase activities.
However, sorbitol and galactose could not be detected in the ‘Baiyu’ loquat flesh. Previous studies indicated that sorbitol was a predominant sugar in young loquat fruit, and only a minor component was involved at the mature stage (Pareek et al., 2014). In ‘Mogi’ and ‘Tanaka’ cultivars, the dominant sugar was fructose and sucrose, respectively (Hamauzu et al., 1997). Xu and Chen (2011) also reported that the percentage of sucrose had significant changes in 12 loquat cultivars. Therefore, sugar contents and types mainly depend on different loquat cultivars and harvested seasons.

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of chitosan/nano-silica treatment on fruit browning index and weight loss
sections.text:
Browning was a main effect factor on postharvest quality and storage life of loquat fruit (Cao et al., 2008). It had attracted much attention of food scientist and food industry. During the whole storage of loquat fruit, the tenth day seemed to be a crucial physiology stage in control fruit, showing a distinct browning (Fig. 3a). The chitosan or nano-silica treated fruit had a milder browning and lesion development than control fruit. The fruit treated with chitosan/nano-silica was not obviously browning until 20 d. The retardation of browning development in treated fruit could be attributed to the slow rate of respiration, caused by a modified internal atmosphere of fruit (Shi et al., 2013). Similar result was shown that low-O2 or high-CO2 atmosphere could delay ripening and senescence of loquat fruit (Ding et al., 2006).
Weight loss in all treated fruit continuously increased along storage periods. Control fruit showed a greater weight loss with an average rate of 1.60% per day, while chitosan/nano-silica coated fruit had a much lower weight loss (Fig. 3b). No significant difference (p = 0.39) was found between chitosan and nano-silica treatment fruit. Although an increase of browning index was generally considered a sign of over-ripeness, chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit developed fewer chilling injury symptoms and exhibited lower weight loss than control or alone treated fruit
(Fig. 3). Thus, combining chitosan with nano-silica may be a more suitable method for commercial application to reduce fruit browning index and maintain fruit weight at cold storage.

sections.heading: 3.4. Effect of chitosan/nano-silica treatment on TSS and TA contents
sections.text:
In control fruit, TSS was sharply increased in the first 5 d, and then declined by the end of storage. Chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit had a higher TSS content, and the peak value (12.47%) was shown on the tenth day (Fig. 4a). A similar rise of TSS was also recorded in mango, banana and longan fruits treated with chitosan and/or nano-silica (Kittur et al., 2001; Shi et al., 2013). Previous studies indicated that the increase of TSS was related to the hydrolytic conversion of starch to sugar, being an important index of fruit ripening process at the initial stage of storage (Arthey and Philip, 2005). The result was supported by the increase of total sugar content as shown in Fig. 2. After that, TSS showed a decline tendency in all fruit samples owing to the decrease of respiration rate. The lowest content of TSS (8.62%) was recorded in control fruit at the end of storage. Therefore, the chitosan/nano-silica coating effectively delayed the decrease of TSS in loquat fruit by modifying the internal atmosphere. But other studies indicated that no significant difference of TSS was shown in chitosan treated and untreated fruit of papaya or zucchini (Bautista-Baños et al., 2006). It might be caused by some confounding factors, such as fruit type, fruit ripeness stage, storage condition or coating concentration and thickness.
Along with a gradual reduction of TSS, severe TA decrease was also found during cold storage (Cao et al., 2011), leading to fresh loquat flavor deterioration. As demonstrated in Supplementary
Table 1, different treatments significantly alleviated the decrease of TA content during storage. Higher level of TA (0.92%) was recorded in chitosan/nano-silica coated fruit followed by chitosan treated fruit (0.68%), while the lowest level was detected in control fruit (0.40%) (Fig. 4b). Similar results were also observed in chitosancoated loquat, mango, and litchi fruits (Zhang et al., 2011; Dong et al., 2004), suggesting that chitosan and/or nano-silica treatment efficiently delayed loquat fruit ripening. This could be related to the metabolic change of fruit or the use of organic acid in the respiratory process (Cao et al., 2009). Although the decrease of TA contents in chitosan or nano-silica treated fruit was inhibited, no significant difference (p = 0.63) was found between of them 30 d before storage. By contrast, the highest TSS/TA ratio (21.51) was shown in control fruit by the end of storage. Goulas et al. (2014) also reported that TA was always higher in ‘Morphitiki’ loquat fruit with a superior taste, resulting in a lower TSS/TA ratio. A central role of TA can be attributed to loquat fruit flavor, while TSS could be used as harvest maturity index as elsewhere proposed. Therefore, delaying the reduction of TA seems to be highly relevant to fulfill consumer’s expectations.

sections.heading: 3.5. Effect of chitosan/nano-silica treatment on ROS production and membrane lipid peroxidation
sections.text:
Stress conditions including chilling or heating treated fruit overproduce ROS such as H2O2 and O2 (Cao et al., 2009). Superfluous ROS caused lipid membrane damage, resulting in a

To measure the integrity of membrane lipid under oxidative stress, MDA and membrane permeability were assessed as direct indicators of membrane injury. During cold storage, MDA increased from 4.46 to 29.63 mmol kg 1 for control fruit, and from 4.35 to 8.31 mmol kg 1 for chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit (Fig. 5c), indicating that the hybrid coating significantly alleviated the peroxidation of membrane lipids, coinciding with lower O2 and H2O2 (Fig. 4a and b). The other evidence was also revealed in dynamic changes of membrane permeability (Fig. 5d). So the chitosan/nano-silica coating delayed fruit senescence and quality deterioration partially due to delaying superoxide generation.

sections.heading: 3.6. Effect of chitosan/nano-silica treatment on PAL and PPO activities
sections.text:
Flesh browning caused by enzymatic oxidation (such as PAL and PPO) was a serious problem for postharvest storage of loquat fruit (Ding et al., 2006). For example, PAL takes part in the synthesis of the phenylpropanoid skeleton (Dixon and Paiva, 1995). PPO catalyzes the oxidation of endogenous polyphenols into quinines, resulting in flesh browning. To better understand effects of chitosan or/and nano-silica on phenolic metabolism of loquat fruit during cold storage, PAL and PPO contents were also determined. PAL activity ascended gradually, and reached a maximum (8632.12 U kg 1) in control fruit by the end of storage. The chitosan/nano-silica coating significantly inhibited the increase of PAL activity (3901.23 U kg 1), followed by 5312.41 and 6892.01 U kg 1 in chitosan or nano-silica treated fruit, respectively (Fig. 6a). Similarly, lower PPO activity was revealed in chitosan/ nano-silica treated loquat fruit, although no obvious difference (p = 0.93) was observed between chitosan and nano-silica treatment (Fig. 6b). It could be a consequence of the chitosan/nanosilica polymer adsorbing suspended PPO, its substrates or products (Lei et al., 2007). Previous studies showed that chitosan can remove metal ions at enzyme active sites by chelating mechanism, and finally render PPO and PAL enzyme inactive (Lai et al., 2006).
Our results revealed the beneficial effect of combination treatment on alleviating the phenolic compound oxidation of loquat fruit.

sections.heading: 3.7. Effect of chitosan/nano-silica treatment on antioxidase and lipoxidase activities
sections.text:
To regulate the balance of oxidative stress caused by chilling injury, some enzyme activities, involving in oxidative metabolism, such as SOD, CAT, APX and LOX, were measured in chitosan or/and nano-silica treated fruit during cold storage.
SOD activities in treated loquat fruit dramatically increased and remained higher than that in control fruit, especially from 10 d to 40 d (Fig. 7a). No significant differences of SOD activity were found between each treatment alone (p = 0.06). High levels of SOD activity could inhibit free radical accumulation by forming H2O2, as evidenced by dynamic changes of H2O2 contents (Fig. 5). To alleviate the oxidative stress, superfluous H2O2 must be converted into non-toxic molecules by other enzymes such as CAT and APX (Noctor and Foyer, 1998). CAT activities in control and treated fruit increased initially, and reached a peak value on the fifth day and on the tenth day of cold storage, respectively. Afterwards, CAT activities in chitosan or/and nano-silica treated fruit were commendably maintained during the remainder storage (Fig. 7b). But a rapid decrease of CAT activity in control fruit cause an increase of H2O2 content (Fig. 5b). Similar results were shown that chitosan treatment enhanced CAT activities in tomato and sweet cherry fruits (Liu et al., 2007; Zhang et al., 2011). APX activities in treated fruit, especially using chitosan/nano-silica treatment, remained also much higher than that in control fruit after 5 d (Fig. 7c). No significant differences in CAT (p = 0.21) or APX (p = 0.17) activity were observed between chitosan and nano-silica treated fruit. Based on the above results, the increases of antioxidant enzyme activities in different treated fruit were effectively enhanced as shown F-values in Supplementary Table 1. Interestingly, control fruit exhibited a sharp increase of LOX activity, while chitosan, nano-silica and chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit showed a relatively stable condition throughout cold storage (Fig. 7d). The above results revealed that the chitosan/nano-silica treatment induced the higher activities of antioxidant enzymes (SOD, CAT and APX) in cold-stored loquat fruit. The superoxide radicals like O2 were converted into H2O2 as a result of high SOD activity. And then, H2O2 was disintegrated into H2O and O2 by CAT and APX activities. It might give rise to the lower LOX activity (Fig. 7d) and the milder membrane permeability (Fig. 5d). However, APX activity was much lower than CAT’s, suggesting that the latter was the key enzyme in H2O2 catabolism of loquat fruit.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: In our present study, the chitosan/nano-silica coating with porous semi-permeable and stable properties, synthesized through the sol-gel approach, was used to evaluate the postharvest preservation of white-flesh loquat fruit at 5 C. These results indicated that the chitosan/nano-silica coating can effectively alleviate internal browning and weight loss and maintain high levels of TSS, TA, glucose and fructose. Glucose and fructose participated into regulating activities of SOD, CAT and APX. Enhanced activities of antioxidant enzymes reduced ROS (O2 or H2O2) accumulation and alleviated membrane lipid peroxidation. Thus, the chitosan/nano-silica coating can induce high activities of antioxidant enzymes regulated by reducing sugars, and enhance chilling tolerance in loquat fruit.

metadata.abstractText: Loquat (Eriobotrya japonica Lindl.) fruit has a very short shelf-life during ambient temperature storage, and is susceptible to cold storage appearing chilling injury symptoms. The effect of chitosan/nano-silica coating on chilling tolerance in white-flesh loquat fruit (cv Baiyu) stored at 5 C for 40 d was investigated. In comparison with control fruit, internal browning and weight loss in chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit were significantly delayed. Likewise, the decrease of total soluble solids (TSS) and titratable acidity (TA) was also inhibited. Glucose and fructose contents increased from 11.31 to 12.76 g kg 1 and from 33.20 to 44.37 g kg , respectively. The increase of reducing sugars contributed to the improvement of superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT) and ascorbate peroxidase (APX) activities, reaching the peaks of 623510.12, 462371.21 and 41114.35 U kg , respectively. Enhanced activities of antioxidant enzymes markedly alleviated the generation of superoxide anion (O2 ) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). Low levels of malondialdehyde (MDA) and membrane permeability in chitosan/nano-silica treated fruit were also detected, ranged from 4.35 to 8.31 mmol kg 1 and from 24.32 to 43.45%, respectively. Moreover, activities of phenylalanine ammonia-lyase (PAL), polyphenoloxidase (PPO) and lipoxidase (LOX) were also much lower than those in treatment alone and control fruit. Our results indicated that the use of chitosan/nanosilica coating was effective in enhancing chilling tolerance and providing a longer storage life with acceptable external and internal quality in loquat fruit. ã 2016 Elsevier B.V.
